greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(0)=2; for n > 0, a(n) = n + floor(sqrt(4n-3)) + 2.
comment: a(0)=2, a(1)=4; for n > 2, a(n) = a(n-1) + 1 if n is already in the sequence, a(n) = a(n-1) + 2 otherwise. [corrected by _Jon E. Schoenfield_, Jun 24 2018]
For n > 0, a(n) = ceiling((1 + sqrt(n))^2). Empirical observation. - _Ronald S. Tiberio_, Jun 24 2018

For n > 0, a(n) is the minimal number of thumbtacks needed to secure n square sheets of paper on a bulletin board - one thumbtack in each corner of each sheet - slight overlap allowed so that one thumbtack can secure up to four sheets. - _Ronald S. Tiberio_, Jun 24 2018
link: B. Cloitre, N. J. A. Sloane and M. J. Vandermast, Numerical analogues of Aronson's sequence, J. Integer Seqs., Vol. 6 (2003), #03.2.2.
B. Cloitre, N. J. A. Sloane and M. J. Vandermast, Numerical analogues of Aronson's sequence, arXiv:math/0305308 [math.NT], 2003.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 14 2003
